image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

title.children: PwC worked for tertiary education regulator as it acquired stake in college

image.altText: A truck dumping stuff on ground at farm.

items.synopsis: Libby Cooper's farm overlooks a picturesque river, but what's happening on a neighbouring area of land has her worried. And she is not the only one.

title.children: Fish kills and stinking fields: Is Tasmania overloaded with industrial rubbish?

image.altText: Isabel Sutherland on the golf course.

items.synopsis: Isabel Sutherland plays two rounds of golf a week and walks about seven kilometres each time. She says it's her key to keeping fit and mobile.

title.children: 'I don't think I'm old': Golf the fountain of youth for 98-year-old Isabel

items.synopsis: It was a Sunday afternoon in Port Arthur in 1996 when the three people Walter Mikac loved most were brutally taken from him.

title.children: Nine days after Walter Mikac lost his entire family, he sent a letter that helped change the course of Australian history

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith looks at the camera outside a court building

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith speaks after arriving back in Australia, and no more trips to Hel on the 666 bus. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ten people remain in hospital four days after the bus crash in the New South Wales Hunter Valley that killed 10 other passengers. A NSW health spokesperson says: Eight people remain in a stable condition at Newcastle's John Hunter hospital Two others are in a stable condition at Sydney's Prince of Wales hospital Dozens were originally hospitalised after being injured in Sunday night's crash, but have since been treated and discharged. Meanwhile, members of the Hunter Valley's AFL community are rolling up their sleeves to replenish blood supplies used in the wake of the bus crash that claimed the lives of several players. Lifeblood says an urgent shipment of blood and plasma was also sent from Sydney to Newcastle in the wake of the crash.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 10 people still in hospital after Hunter Valley bus crash

children.content: Ten people remain in hospital four days after the
bus crash in the New South Wales Hunter Valley that killed 10 other passengers
A NSW health spokesperson says:
Eight people remain in a stable condition at Newcastle's John Hunter hospital
Two others are in a stable condition at Sydney's Prince of Wales hospital
Dozens were originally hospitalised
after being injured in Sunday night's crash, but have since been treated and discharged.
Meanwhile,
members of the Hunter Valley's AFL community are rolling up their sleeves
to replenish blood supplies used in the wake of the bus crash that claimed the lives of several players.
Lifeblood says an urgent shipment of blood and plasma was also sent from Sydney to Newcastle in the wake of the crash.

props.alt: A white man sitting in a chair giving blood

children.content: Matthew Norris from the Maitland Saints Australian Football Club has given blood this week.
(ABC News: Alexander Lewis)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Controversial Australian soldier Ben Roberts Smith has arrived back in Australia in the wake of a Federal Court ruling against him. The corporal unsuccessfully sued the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age and Canberra Times for defamation, with the court finding allegations of murder and bullying during his deployment to Afghanistan were substantially true. Speaking to Channel Nine in Perth, Roberts-Smith says his legal team will review the judgement. "I'm devastated with the result. It's a terrible outcome and it's the incorrect outcome," he says. "We will look at it and consider whether or not we need to file an appeal but there's not much more I can say about it. "We'll just have to work through it and I'll take the advice as it comes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ben Roberts-Smith speaks after arriving back in Australia

props.alt: A white man with short hair wearing a suit

children.content: (AAP: Dan Himbrechts)
Controversial Australian soldier Ben Roberts Smith has arrived back in Australia in the wake of a Federal Court ruling against him.
The corporal unsuccessfully sued the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age and Canberra Times for defamation, with
the court finding allegations of murder and bullying during his deployment to Afghanistan were substantially true
Speaking to Channel Nine in Perth, Roberts-Smith says his legal team will review the judgement.
"I'm devastated with the result. It's a terrible outcome and it's the incorrect outcome," he says.
"We will look at it and consider whether or not we need to file an appeal but there's not much more I can say about it.
"We'll just have to work through it and I'll take the advice as it comes."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the US, the Federal Reserve has decided to keep its key interest rate unchanged after 10 consecutive increases. The central bank's move to l eave its benchmark rate at between 5 and 5.25 per cent suggests it believes the much higher borrowing rates it's engineered have made some progress in taming inflation. The Fed has raised its benchmark rate by a substantial five percentage points since March last year — the fastest pace of increases in 40 years. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says most policy makers expect it'll be appropriate for rates to be raised again this year. "But at this meeting, considering how far and how fast we've moved, we judged it prudent to hold the target range steady, to allow the committee to assess additional information and its implications for monetary policy," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US Fed pauses key interest rate after 10 straight increases

props.alt: A white man in a suit and glasses stands at a podium in front of US flags and speaks and gestures with his hands

children.content: (Reuters: Kevin Lamarque)
In the US, the Federal Reserve has decided to keep its key interest rate unchanged
after 10 consecutive increases
The central bank's move to l
eave its benchmark rate at between 5 and 5.25 per cent
suggests it believes the much higher borrowing rates it's engineered have made some progress in taming inflation.
The Fed has raised its benchmark rate by a substantial five percentage points since March last year — the fastest pace of increases in 40 years.
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says most policy makers expect it'll be appropriate for rates to be raised again this year.

"But at this meeting, considering how far and how fast we've moved, we judged it prudent to hold the target range steady, to allow the committee to assess additional information and its implications for monetary policy," he says.

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

items.synopsis: The US Federal Reserve pauses its current interest rate hike cycle after 10 straight increases, while local investors await the release of the latest employment figures. Follow live.

title.children: US pauses interest rate rises but flags more hikes may be necessary, ASX to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB's chief economist Alan Oster was speaking to Hamish Macdonald on RN Breakfast a short time ago about the US Federal Reserve leaving interest rates on hold overnight. He said the rate pause was expected, but was taken by surprise when the members of the Fed considered the future of rate rises in the current cycle. "What wasn't expected was essentially that they have what's called the dots in other words, all the members of the Fed vote for where they think rates are gonna go," he said. "And the average said two more rate rises. That was a surprise."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed's rate pause wasn't a surprise, but 'two more rate rises' was

children.content: NAB's chief economist
Alan Oster
was speaking to Hamish Macdonald on
RN Breakfast
a short time ago about the US Federal Reserve leaving interest rates on hold overnight.
He said the rate pause was expected, but was taken by surprise when the members of the Fed considered the future of rate rises in the current cycle.
"What wasn't expected was essentially that they have what's called the dots in other words, all the members of the Fed vote for where they think rates are gonna go," he said.
"And the average said two more rate rises. That was a surprise."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PricewaterhouseCoopers began work on a top-level consulting contract with the federal government's regulator of tertiary colleges 24 hours before agreeing to acquire a $5.5 million stake in one such college, the controversial Top Education Group. In addition, eight senior partners of PwC — including two who oversaw the firm while it misused confidential Treasury data, prompting a global crisis — personally invested another $2.5 million in the company a year later. You can read more of this story from ABC Investigations below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC acquired stake in international college while consulting the tertiary regulator

featuredLink.title: PwC invested in college while consulting to tertiary education regulator

children.content: PricewaterhouseCoopers began work on a top-level consulting contract with the federal government's regulator of tertiary colleges 24 hours before agreeing to acquire a
$5.5 million stake in one such college
, the controversial Top Education Group.
In addition, eight senior partners of PwC — including
two who oversaw the firm while it misused confidential Treasury data
, prompting a global crisis — personally invested another $2.5 million in the company a year later.
You can read more of this story from
ABC Investigations
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Thursday, June 15 and you're reading the ABC's markets and business blog. Let's start with the big news overnight, which was the US Federal Reserve deciding to keep interest rates on hold at 5% to 5.25%. The Fed elected to hit pause on the current rate hike cycle, which has so far seen 10 consecutive rate rises. But even though the US won't see rates rising this month, Fed chairman Jerome Powell said there may be more rate rises on the way. "Looking ahead, nearly all committee participants view it as likely that some further rate increases will be appropriate this year to bring inflation down to 2% over time," Powell said at a press conference. The reason? Persistent inflation in the US economy that's taking time to come down. "Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year, nonetheless, inflation pressures continue to run high and the process of getting inflation down to 2% has a long way to go," he said. Naturally, a statement like that sent Wall Street trade down, but things steadied towards the close of trade, with a mixed result. Back home and all eyes are eagerly watching for the latest unemployment figures, which will be out at 11:30am AEST. As for what analysts are predicting, the Commonwealth Bank is expecting the unemployment rate will remain steady at 3.7%, with around 20,000 new jobs added. Data on consumer inflation expectations and population growth are also being released today, while the ASX is set to open higher after some positive gains in the futures overnight. All in all, there's a bit on! Stick with us and let's get into it.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Future rate hikes not ruled out in the US as ASX set to open higher

children.content: Good morning, it's
Thursday, June 15
and you're reading the ABC's markets and business blog.
Let's start with the big news overnight, which was the US Federal Reserve deciding to keep
interest rates on hold at 5% to 5.25%
The Fed elected to hit pause on the current rate hike cycle, which has so far seen 10 consecutive rate rises.
But even though the US won't see rates rising this month, Fed chairman
Jerome Powell
said there
may be more rate rises on the way
"Looking ahead, nearly all committee participants view it as likely that some further rate increases will be appropriate this year to bring inflation down to 2% over time," Powell said at a press
conference.
The reason? Persistent inflation in the US economy that's taking time to come down.
"Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year, nonetheless, inflation pressures continue to run high and the process of getting inflation down to 2% has a long way to go," he said.
Naturally, a statement like that sent Wall Street trade down, but things steadied towards the close of trade, with a mixed result.
Back home and all eyes are eagerly watching for the latest
unemployment figures
, which will be out at 11:30am AEST.
As for what analysts are predicting, the Commonwealth Bank is expecting the
unemployment rate will remain steady at 3.7%
, with around 20,000 new jobs added.
Data on consumer inflation expectations and population growth are also being released today, while the ASX is set to open higher after some positive gains in the futures overnight.
All in all, there's a bit on! Stick with us and let's get into it.
